title: Lib Dems claim Brexit threatens £60 million EU funding for North East jobs
text:

Prime Minister Theresa May has been accused of putting at risk a £60 million EU loan to create thousands of North East jobs. 
The European Investment Bank (EIB) is considering an application for £60 million to go towards the £145m North East Fund, which will provide loans and investment to firms in the region. 
But there are reports that the money could be withheld because Mrs May is demanding the return of £9bn of UK assets currently held by the EIB. 
It’s part of the Government’s attempts to reduce the UK’s bill for leaving the EU when Brexit takes place. 
Concerns were raised by Liberal Democrat leader Tim Farron. He said: “This government is jeopardising vital investment for the North East through its reckless approach to Brexit. 
“Ministers have refused to guarantee future regional funds post-Brexit, now they are risking a £60m loan by unnecessarily antagonising our European partners. 
“It is a short-sighted approach that risks short-changing the North East. 
“You can’t have a hard Brexit and the investment we need to create a strong, stable economy.” European Union flag in front of Big Ben 
The North East Fund was created by the Department for Communities and Local Government and seven North East councils, and is expected to provide support for 600 businesses and create up to 3,500 jobs. 
According to the European Investment Bank, the bid for £60 million is currently under appraisal. 
Meanwhile, Mrs May has urged MPs to stop describing Brexit as a divorce - because it suggests the UK and European Union will be on bad terms after they split. Read More Theresa May to trigger Article 50 by end of March after victories in Parliament 
The Prime Minister told MPs they need to “stop looking at this as simply coming out of the European Union” and recognise instead the opportunity to forge a new relationship with the bloc. 
She said she preferred not to use the word “divorce” to characterise proceedings with the EU because “very often when people get divorced they don’t have a very good relationship afterwards”. 
But she faced warnings from the Scottish National Party, which has announced plans to call for a fresh referendum on Scottish independence, that the British Government will face “consequences” if it fails to secure a UK-wide approach to Brexit negotiations. Prime Minister Theresa May (Photo: PA) 
Angus Robertson, the SNP’s Westminster leader, accused the Prime Minster of rebuffing repeated attempts from the Scottish Parliament in Holyrood at a Brexit compromise, and urged her to get the backing of all parts of the UK for her strategy. 
He said: “Last July we were told by the Prime Minister herself, and I am sure she remembers saying these very words, that she would not trigger Article 50 until she had ‘a UK-wide approach’. 
“Now she knows that she has no agreement with the devolved administration, despite months of compromise suggestions from the Scottish Government. 
“So, will the UK Government, even at this very late stage, use the next days to secure a compromise UK-wide approach, or does she still plan to plough on regardless, even though she knows of the consequences that will mean?” A Union Jack flag flutters in front of Big Ben (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
The Prime Minister said Britain has been in talks with all the devolved administrations about negotiations to leave the EU and said there is no appetite in Scotland for another referendum. 
She said: “We have been in discussions with the Scottish Government and the other devolved administrations, recognising the issues that they have raised, recognising the issues and concerns and the common ground between us. 
“But you refer to the views of the Scottish people in relation to the announcement made yesterday by the Scottish First Minister, I might remind him that the evidence in Scotland is that actually the majority of the Scottish people do not want a second independence referendum.” 
And she stressed that it is in Scotland’s economic interests to stay part of the United Kingdom’s single market, rather than abandoning it to keep its relationship with Brussels.” 
A Government spokesperson said: "As long as we continue to be a full member of the EU, we remain a full member of the European Investment Bank and would expect UK projects' applications to be considered in the normal way." Like us on Facebook
